message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Argumentation and explainable artificial intelligence: a survey
Paper Abstract: Abstract Argumentation and eXplainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) are closely related, as in the recent years, Argumentation has been used for providing Explainability to AI. Argumentation can show step by step how an AI System reaches a decision; it can provide reasoning over uncertainty and can find solutions when conflicting information is faced. In this survey, we elaborate over the topics of Argumentation and XAI combined, by reviewing all the important methods and studies, as well as implementations that use Argumentation to provide Explainability in AI. More specifically, we show how Argumentation can enable Explainability for solving various types of problems in decision-making, justification of an opinion, and dialogues. Subsequently, we elaborate on how Argumentation can help in constructing explainable systems in various applications domains, such as in Medical Informatics, Law, the Semantic Web, Security, Robotics, and some general purpose systems. Finally, we present approaches that combine Machine Learning and Argumentation Theory, toward more interpretable predictive models.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "Machine learning Wikipedia" and retrieved results from the Wikipedia article on machine learning along with related topics. Here are some key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## History

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine. Additionally, the application of ML to business problems is known as predictive analytics.

## Recent Advances

Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

For more detailed information, you can visit the main Wikipedia article on Machine Learning directly.

I've completed a web search for "Machine learning Wikipedia" and retrieved results from the Wikipedia article on machine learning along with related topics. Here are some key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## History

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine. Additionally, the application of ML to business problems is known as predictive analytics.

## Recent Advances

Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

For more detailed information, you can visit the main Wikipedia article on Machine Learning directly.

Here are the search results for "Robotics Wikipedia":

## Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

## Key Components

Robotics usually combines three aspects of design work: mechanical construction (a frame, form or shape designed to achieve a particular task), electrical components that power and control the machinery, and software (a program is how a robot decides when or how to do something).

## Historical Origins

The word "robot" was introduced to the public by Czech writer Karel Čapek in his play R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots), published in 1920.(no content)The term "robotics" was coined by Isaac Asimov in his 1941 science fiction short-story "Liar!"

## Modern Applications

Robotics technologies deal with automated machines that can take the place of humans in dangerous environments or manufacturing processes, or resemble humans in appearance, behaviour, and or cognition.(no content)Many of today's robots are inspired by nature contributing to the field of bio-inspired robotics.

I've completed a web search for "Decision making Wikipedia." Here are the key findings from the search results:

## Main Definition

In psychology, decision-making is regarded as the cognitive process resulting in the selection of a belief or a course of action among several possible alternative options.(no content)It could be either rational or irrational.

## Key Aspects of Decision-Making

**Analysis of Alternatives:** A major part of decision-making involves the analysis of a finite set of alternatives described in terms of evaluative criteria, with the task being to rank these alternatives in terms of how attractive they are to the decision-maker(s) when all the criteria are considered simultaneously.

**Types of Decision-Making:**
- Logical decision-making is an important part of all science-based professions, where specialists apply their knowledge in a given area to make informed decisions. For example, medical decision-making often involves a diagnosis and the selection of appropriate treatment.
- In situations with higher time pressure, higher stakes, or increased ambiguities, experts may use intuitive decision-making rather than structured approaches, following a recognition-primed decision that fits their experience.

**Environmental Factors:** The decision-maker's environment can play a part in the decision-making process, with environmental complexity being a factor that influences cognitive function.

The search results cover various Wikipedia articles on decision-making, including topics like decision-making models, group decision-making, intuition in decision-making, and dynamic decision-making.

Links: [{"title":"Semantic Web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web"},{"title":"Category:Semantic Web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Semantic_Web"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Semantic Wikipedia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Semantic_Wikipedia"},{"title":"Social Semantic Web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Semantic_Web"},{"title":"Semantic web service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_web_service"},{"title":"Semantic wiki - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_wiki"},{"title":"Template:Semantic Web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Semantic_Web"},{"title":"Semantic Web Stack - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web_Stack"},{"title":"Talk:Semantic Web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Semantic_Web"},{"title":"Semantic Web Services Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web_Services_Language"}]

I found the Wikipedia article on the Semantic Web. Here are the key points:

## Overview

The Semantic Web, sometimes known as Web 3.0, is an extension of the World Wide Web through standards set by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C).(no content)The goal of the Semantic Web is to make Internet data machine-readable.

## Key Technologies

To enable the encoding of semantics with the data, technologies such as Resource Description Framework (RDF) and Web Ontology Language (OWL) are used.(no content)Ontology can describe concepts, relationships between entities, and categories of things, and these embedded semantics offer significant advantages such as reasoning over data and operating with heterogeneous data sources.

## History and Vision

The term was coined by Tim Berners-Lee for a web of data (or data web) that can be processed by machines—that is, one in which much of the meaning is machine-readable.(no content)Berners-Lee originally expressed his vision of the Semantic Web in 1999 as a web in which computers become capable of analyzing all the data on the Web, and when this emerges, the day-to-day mechanisms of trade, bureaucracy and our daily lives will be handled by machines talking to machines.

## Current Status

While its critics have questioned its feasibility, proponents argue that applications in library and information science, industry, biology and human sciences research have already proven the validity of the original concept.

## Overview

The Semantic Web, sometimes known as Web 3.0, is an extension of the World Wide Web through standards set by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C).(no content)The goal of the Semantic Web is to make Internet data machine-readable.

## Key Technologies

To enable the encoding of semantics with the data, technologies such as Resource Description Framework (RDF) and Web Ontology Language (OWL) are used.(no content)Ontology can describe concepts, relationships between entities, and categories of things, and these embedded semantics offer significant advantages such as reasoning over data and operating with heterogeneous data sources.

## History and Vision

The term was coined by Tim Berners-Lee for a web of data (or data web) that can be processed by machines—that is, one in which much of the meaning is machine-readable.(no content)Berners-Lee originally expressed his vision of the Semantic Web in 1999 as a web in which computers become capable of analyzing all the data on the Web, and when this emerges, the day-to-day mechanisms of trade, bureaucracy and our daily lives will be handled by machines talking to machines.

## Current Status

While its critics have questioned its feasibility, proponents argue that applications in library and information science, industry, biology and human sciences research have already proven the validity of the original concept.

I've successfully performed a web search for "Dialogue systems Wikipedia". Here are the key results:

## Main Wikipedia Article on Dialogue Systems

Simple dialogue systems are widely used to decrease the human workload in call centers, with this functionality in industrial telephony applications known as interactive voice response or IVR.

### Key Components

Principal to any dialogue system is the dialogue manager, which is a component that manages the state of the dialogue, and dialogue strategy.(no content)The semantic information is analysed by the dialogue manager, which keeps the history and state of the dialogue and manages the general flow of the conversation, and usually contacts one or more task managers that have knowledge of the specific task domain.

### Modern Developments

In the 2020s, dialogue systems have increasingly been built on top of large language models (LLMs), which allow them to handle open-domain conversation more flexibly than earlier rule-based or statistical approaches.(no content)Modern implementations often integrate both voice and text interfaces, providing users with multi-modal interaction through conversational agents, and such systems are also being embedded into applications with user-friendly interfaces for customer service, education, and personal assistance.

### Applications

Dialogue systems can support a broad range of applications in business enterprises, education, government, healthcare, and entertainment.

The search also returned related articles on spoken dialog systems, dialogue trees, and dialog managers with additional technical details about these systems.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI):

## Definition

Explainable AI (XAI), generally overlapping with interpretable AI or explainable machine learning (XML), is a field of research that explores methods that provide humans with the ability of intellectual oversight over AI algorithms.

## Purpose and Goals

XAI aims to explain what has been done, what is being done, and what will be done next, and to unveil which information these actions are based on. This makes it possible to confirm existing knowledge, challenge existing knowledge, and generate new assumptions.

## Core Principles

XAI algorithms follow the three principles of transparency, interpretability, and explainability.

## Types of AI Models

Machine learning (ML) algorithms used in AI can be categorized as white-box or black-box. White-box models provide results that are understandable to experts in the domain. Black-box models, on the other hand, are extremely hard to explain and may not be understood even by domain experts.

## Practical Approaches

Several technical approaches have been developed to address XAI: SHAP enables to visualise the contribution of each feature to the output. LIME can locally approximate a model's outputs with a simpler, interpretable model.

## Importance

As regulators, official bodies, and general users come to depend on AI-based dynamic systems, clearer accountability will be required for automated decision-making processes to ensure trust and transparency.

I found relevant Wikipedia articles on argumentation. Here's an overview of the key information:

## Main Article: Argumentation Theory

Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning.(no content)With historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric, argumentation theory includes the arts and sciences of civil debate, dialogue, conversation, and persuasion.(no content)It studies rules of inference, logic, and procedural rules in both artificial and real-world settings.(no content)Argumentation includes various forms of dialogue such as deliberation and negotiation which are concerned with collaborative decision-making procedures, as well as eristic dialogue (where victory over an opponent is the primary goal) and didactic dialogue used for teaching.

## Related Topics Found

The search also returned articles on:

- **Argumentation Schemes**: An argumentation scheme or argument scheme is a template that represents a common type of argument used in ordinary conversation.

- **Argumentation Frameworks**: In artificial intelligence and related fields, an argumentation framework is a way to deal with contentious information and draw conclusions from it using formalized arguments.

- **Logic of Argumentation**: The logic of argumentation (LA) is a formalised description of the ways in which humans reason and argue about propositions.

These articles cover the theoretical, practical, and computational aspects of argumentation.

Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning.(no content)With historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric, argumentation theory includes the arts and sciences of civil debate, dialogue, conversation, and persuasion.(no content)It studies rules of inference, logic, and procedural rules in both artificial and real-world settings.(no content)Argumentation includes various forms of dialogue such as deliberation and negotiation which are concerned with collaborative decision-making procedures, as well as eristic dialogue (where victory over an opponent is the primary goal) and didactic dialogue used for teaching.

## Related Topics Found

The search also returned articles on:

- **Argumentation Schemes**: An argumentation scheme or argument scheme is a template that represents a common type of argument used in ordinary conversation.

- **Argumentation Frameworks**: In artificial intelligence and related fields, an argumentation framework is a way to deal with contentious information and draw conclusions from it using formalized arguments.

- **Logic of Argumentation**: The logic of argumentation (LA) is a formalised description of the ways in which humans reason and argue about propositions.

These articles cover the theoretical, practical, and computational aspects of argumentation.
